Pressure Range: 15 bar absorption, 10⁻⁴ bar desorption; 15 bar (absorption), 10⁻⁴ bar (desorption); 10⁻⁴ bar
Synthesis Method: reduction‑induced decomposition (RID) of MgCl₂ (solution‑based); facile organic solution‑based approach without harsh etching
Key Findings: Porous Mg shows >6 wt% H₂ uptake and markedly faster absorption kinetics than spherical Mg nanoparticles.; BET surface area rose from 3.10 to 8.45 m² g⁻¹ after cycling; crystallite size increased to 70.61 nm.; Surface penetration limits H absorption on (002) and (101) facets; (100) shows minimal discontinuity.; Activation energy for H absorption/desorption measured; values vary with hydrogen concentration.; Absorption Ea ≈80 kJ mol⁻¹, desorption Ea ≈180 kJ mol⁻¹; ΔH −67.2/78.1 kJ mol⁻¹ H₂; nanoporous Mg shows faster kinetics than bulk Mg.
Comments: Hydrogen capacity and kinetics improve over the first four cycles.; Porous structure retained; average pore width reduced to ~35 nm after cycling.; Activation reduces (002) surfaces, increasing (100) facet proportion.; Overall activation energy values summarized in Table 2 (specific numbers not given).; Ligament size up to ~200 nm; pores evolve from open to closed during cycling.

Pressure Range: 15 bar absorption, 10⁻⁴ bar desorption; 15 bar (absorption), 10⁻⁴ bar (desorption); 10⁻⁴ bar
Synthesis Method: reduction‑induced decomposition (RID) of MgCl₂ with Ni dopant (solution‑based); facile organic solution‑based approach without harsh etching
Key Findings: Ni‑doped porous Mg reaches 6.41 wt% H₂ capacity and exhibits accelerated sorption rates due to catalytic Ni.; Requires fewer activation cycles than pMg, attributed to Ni catalytic role.; Ni doping reduces surface H desorption barrier to 0.98 eV under 3 % compression and diffusion barriers to ~0.27 eV, accelerating dehydrogenation.; Absorption Ea 80–150 kJ mol⁻¹, desorption Ea ~100 kJ mol⁻¹; ΔH −69.9/86.7 kJ mol⁻¹ H₂; Mg₂Ni phase (<5 nm) forms, enhancing catalytic effect.
Comments: Capacity stabilizes at ~6 wt% (absorption) / 6.5 wt% (desorption); drops 0.8 wt% at cycle 40 and 1.1 wt% at cycle 50.; Mg (002) XRD intensity reduction observed but less pronounced than in pMg.; Kinetics become limited by hydride decomposition after Ni addition.; Ni incorporation lowers activation barriers and improves sorption rates.

Synthesis Method: Reduction of MgCl2 (0.952 g, 0.01 mol) with lithium naphthalenide solution (Li 0.207 g, 0.03 mol; naphthalene 3.85 g, 0.03 mol) for 4 days under Ar, followed by washing and vacuum drying.; RID reaction using MgCl2 and lithium naphthalenide
Key Findings: Nanoporous Mg shows gradually improved hydrogen storage performance (rate and capacity) due to crystalline phase recovery and stress effects.
Comments: Doping with NiI2 or CoCl2 (5 mol %) also explored.; Patents describe preparation of porous Mg and bimetallic composites

Pressure Range: 15 bar absorption, 10⁻⁴ bar desorption; 15 bar (absorption), 10⁻⁴ bar (desorption); 10⁻⁴ bar
Synthesis Method: reduction‑induced decomposition (RID) of MgCl₂ with Co dopant (solution‑based); facile organic solution‑based approach without harsh etching
Key Findings: Co‑doped porous Mg shows >6 wt% H₂ uptake with enhanced sorption kinetics compared to pure Mg.; Rapid activation observed; CoO impurity peaks detected in XRD.; Activation energy data reported in Table 2 (specific values not provided in text).; Absorption Ea ≈70 kJ mol⁻¹, desorption Ea ~140 kJ mol⁻¹; ΔH −66.1/81.5 kJ mol⁻¹ H₂; Mg₂Co phase (<5 nm) provides fast hydrogen pathways.
Comments: Kinetic saturation occurs faster than in pure Mg, similar to pMgNi.; Mg (002) intensity change minimal before and after cycling.; Co addition reduces activation energy for absorption compared to pure pMg.

Key Findings: Shows enhanced hydrogen sorption kinetics and capacity up to 6 wt.% after cycling; compressive stress during hydrogenation accelerates kinetics.
Comments: Facet‑dependent sorption; porous structure mitigates 33 % volume change.
